hedline.hl1: The L.I.R.R. Train That Lays Its Own Track

abstract.p: Photo essay shows slow-moving, quarter-mile-long machine that Long Island Railroad is using to replace old wooden ties with concrete ones in Port Washington (M)

block.p: THE machine is almost a quarter-mile long and creeps along at 800 feet an hour, replacing old track with new. This behemoth, right, is being used by the Long Island Rail Road to replace old wooden ties with concrete ones, which last three times longer and require less maintenance. The machine pulls up the old rail, removes the ties, plows out the track bed and installs the rails on new concrete ties.

THE machine is almost a quarter-mile long and creeps along at 800 feet an hour, replacing old track with new. This behemoth, right, is being used by the Long Island Rail Road to replace old wooden ties with concrete ones, which last three times longer and require less maintenance. The machine pulls up the old rail, removes the ties, plows out the track bed and installs the rails on new concrete ties.

Two sections of line are being worked on this season: the Port Washington branch and the main line west of Jamaica. In Port Washington, a work crew, top left, followed the machine, adjusting the rails on a newly laid section. While the machine was at work in Queens, a worker, far left, guided a section of rail onto new ties, while Web Merrithew manned a control panel that guided new ties along a conveyer belt to the bed. Below, old ties are ready to be recycled.
